title-group.article-title: Effective active vibration control of single link flexible manipulator with modified positive position feedback control in the presence of instrumentation phase lead/lag

contrib-group.aff: Department of (I & P) Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Jalandhar, Punjab, India

author-notes.corresp: Rajiv Kumar, Department of (I & P) Engineering, National Institute of Technology, Jalandhar, Punjab, India Email: rajivsharma1972@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Accurate trajectory regulation of flexible link manipulators is a challenging task. The presence of hardware filters with the cut-off frequency near the resonant frequency cause an additional closed loop instability problem in the control system. This problem can be solved using modified Kalman filters along with certain hardware circuits called compensators. A linear quadratic Gaussian controller has been used to control the hub position. A positive position feedback (PPF) controller has been used at the piezoelectric actuators at the flexible link in the present work to minimize the end-effector vibrations. Normally the design parameters (i.e. coefficients of the numerator and denominator polynomial) of the PPF controller are selected by hit and trial. Pattern search technique has been used as an efficient design method to design these controllers which otherwise have no systematic way to design.

sec.title: 1. Introduction and problem formulation
sec.p: Robotic manipulators are widely used to help in dangerous, monotonous, and tedious jobs.

Most of the existing robotic manipulators are designed and built in a manner to maximize stiffness in an attempt to minimize the vibration of the end-effector to achieve a good position accuracy. This high stiffness is achieved by using heavy material and a bulky design. Hence, the existing heavy rigid manipulators are shown to be inefficient in terms of power consumption or speed with respect to the operating payload. For these purposes it is highly desirable to build flexible robotic manipulators. These conflicting requirements between high speed and high positioning accuracy have rendered the robotic assembly task a challenging research problem. In order to improve industrial productivity, it is required to reduce the weight of the arms and/or to increase their speed of operation. Due to the importance and usefulness of these topics, researchers worldwide are nowadays engaged in the investigation of dynamics and control of flexible link manipulators as reported by Book (1993), Moudgal et al. (1994), Choi et al. (1995). Choi and Shin (1996) and Yang et al., (1997).

In order to achieve high precision in tip positioning, the use of tip position measurement is essential. Cannon and Schmitz (1994) initiated the experiment to control the tip positioning of aflexible manipulator by using the measurement from a tip positioning sensor as a feedback input. They designed a linear quadratic Gaussian (LQG) controller and the obtained results suggested a satisfactory step response with accurate tip positioning. However, the LQG controller was not robust with respect to modeling errors. It was concluded that if the modeling error has to be considered, robust controllers based on H∞ optimization, are the best option.

To enhance the flexible link’s vibration damping property, additional sensors and actuators can be applied, which was proposed by Luo (1993). When modeling the flexible links, the assumed mode method or finite element method (FEM) is most often used to obtain the discrete dynamic model for the flexible link. On parallel lines, research has been intensifying over the past two decades regarding active vibration control methods for structures using smart materials. The widely used smart materials for vibration control in structures are piezoelectric materials since they have desirable characteristics. Based on these characteristics, piezoelectric materials are being used as sensors and actuators. By using piezoceramic actuators (i.e. lead zirconate titanate or PZT patches) bonded to the flexible link, the link vibrations can be suppressed through a combination of hub motion control and control of PZT actuators. In the context of PZT patch control design, Sun et al. (2004) studied the active vibration control of a flexible link damping problem using a combined scheme of hub proportional derivative (PD) feedback and linear velocity (so called ‘L-type’) feedback of PZT actuators.

Shan et al. (2005) showed that the L-type control of the distributed PZT patches was only conditionally stable and that to ensure stability, the PZT patches had to be placed in spots where the curvature of the link would not inflect across the domain of the patch. To be safe, it was recommended that the L-type PZT patches be placed only at the hub or the tip of the beam to ensure satisfaction of this condition. This work was extended to rotating cantilever beams by Sun and Mills (2002) and Sun et al. (2005). Only recently, Gurses et al. (2009) investigated on a new shape sensor, ShapeTape™ from Measurand Inc. It was used as an effective feedback sensor for active vibration damping of the flexible link. ShapeTape™ is an array of fiber optic curvature sensors laminated on a thin flexible ribbon substrate/tape, arranged to sense its bends and twist. This resulted in a more effective vibration damping controller.

Many control strategies such as velocity feedback, neural networks, genetic algorithms, adaptive control and fuzzy control were reported by various researchers (Mayhan and Washington, 1998; Jha and Rower, 2002; Ma, 2003; Silva et al., 2004; Sun et al., 2004), respectively. These strategies have been tested for the regulation and vibration control of flexible link manipulators. Positive position feedback (PPF) was introduced by Goh and Caughey (1985) for the control of flexible structures. An autonomous control technique was developed using online pole zero identification to design optimal feedback compensator (McEver and Leo, 2001). The PPF controller has several advantages compared to the widely used other control laws:
It is insensitive to control spillover, where contributions from unmodeled dynamics affect the control of the modes of interest.
It can offer quick damping for a particular mode provided that modal characteristics are well known.
It is easy to implement.

Based on these characteristics, PPF control design technique has been tested in the present research work. Normally, PPF control is not optimal for all the modes. Its tuning for optimality for any particular mode reduces the damping effect for other modes of interest.

Moheimani et al. (2006) provided the conditions for optimality. However, the presence of hardware in the loop reduces the effectiveness of the designed controller. In case of flexible manipulators, the first natural frequency is generally low (normally less than 10 Hz). In some cases it as low as 1.5 Hz. Applications of high pass filters to remove the direct current (DC) off-set changes the dynamics of the overall system causing instability in the designed control system. Similarly due to a low pass filter and time delay element closed loop system performance degrades.

Hence the PPF controller should be designed to compensate such factors. In the present work LQG control has been applied for hub angle regulation. PPF control is applied at the PZT actuator for reducing the vibrations of the end-effector. The total contribution of the present research work can be divided as follows:- (1) the negative effect of hardware filters has been compensated by redesigning the Kalman filters. (2) PPF controller has been designed using pattern search tools which automatically compensate the effect of hardware filters, although with the help of specially designed hardware compensation circuits 3) Using pattern search technique, the H2 or H∞ norm of the closed loop system is reduced as a result of which no particular mode is left without being damped. Optimal damping is added to all the modes of significance.

sec.title: 2. Experimental set-up
sec.p:
The flexible manipulator used here consists of a steel beam (950 mm × 36 mm × 1.4 mm) clamped directly to the shaft of a Glentic GM 4040-41 DC brush servomotor. An illustration of the experimental set-up is shown in Figure 1 as below. Figure 1.
Experimental set-up for the single link manipulator.
The motor was driven by a Glentek GA 377 pulse width modulation servo amplifier.

The motor has a continuous stall torque of 3.54 Nm and a maximum bandwidth of 58 Hz. The shaft encoder of the motor was used to measure the hub angle rotation. It has a least count of 0.072o. An MA-17 high voltage amplifier was used to amplify the signal to be given to the PZT actuator. An infrared light-emitting diode (LED) and a Hamamatsu S 1352 position sensitive detector was used to measure the tip deflection of the beam. The LED was fixed on the top of the hub. A Hamamatsu C 5923 signal processing unit was used to drive the infrared LED. A dSPACE DS 1103 controller board was used for real time control application. A sampling frequency of 30 kHz was used in order to avoid aliasing.

sec.title: 3. Dynamic finite element and analytical modeling of flexible link
3.1. Finite element modeling of flexible link
sec.p: The flexible link, shown in Figure 1(c), is modeled as a slender flexible beam rigidly attached to a rotating hub using the FEM. The Euler Bernoulli beam theory is applied and axial deformation is neglected. The flexible link is assembled using n elements - the hub is node 0 and the tip of the beam is node n. First considered is the ith beam element, extending between nodes i-1 and i, which has two surface bonded PZT patches and is hereafter referred to as a piezo-beam element. The transverse elastic deflection through the ith element is assumed to follow (Logan, 1992) (1)wi(x)=a1x3+a2x2+a3x+a4 where the x axis originates at node i-land is aligned with the deformed piezo-beam element.

Applying boundary conditions on the deflection and slope and factoring the nodal degree-of-freedom (d.f.) produces the classic cubic Hermitian shape functions, N1 through N4 as reported by Logan (1992). (2)wi(x,t)=N(x)di(t) where N(x)=[N1N2N3N4], di(t)={dy(i-1)φ(i-1)dy(i)φ(i)}N1=1L3(2x3-3x2L+L3),N2=1L3(x3L-2x2L2+xL3)N3=1L3(-2x3+3x2L), N4=1L3(x3L-x2L2) where L denotes the length of the ith element, N(x) is matrix of the shape functions, and di(t) is the vector containing the nodal d.f. - two translational (dy(i-1) at node i − 1 and dy(i) at node i) and two rotational (Φ(i−1) at node i − 1 and Φ(i) at node i) of the ith element. The absolute position of an arbitrary point within the ith element with respect to the inertial coordinate frame (XY) is (Sun et al., 2004) (3)p=[pXpY]=[xcθ-w(x,t)sθxsθ+w(x,t)cθ]

Where sθ = sin θ(t), cθ = cos θ(t), and x = x(i−1) + x in which x(i−1) is the location of the node i−1 on the flexible link. The kinetic energy of the ith element is given by: (4)Ti=12∫0L(ρbAb+ρpAp)(p·X2+p·Y2)dx

Where (ρb, Ab) and (ρp, Ap) respectively denote the density and cross-section area of the beam and the perfectly bonded PZT patch, and p·X=∂pX/∂t. The strain energy of the ith element is then defined as: (5)U=12∫0L(EI)(w″i)2dx where (EI) is a homogenized flexural rigidity calculated for piezo-beam element cross section and w″=∂2w(x,t)/∂x2. The (EI) value accounts for the independent values of the Young’s moduli, Eb and Ep and the moments of inertia, Ib and Ip of the beam and PZT material about the y axis. The use of the homogeneous (EI) value assumes that the PZT patch is perfectly bonded to the surface of the beam element, and that the curvature of the beam centerline completely defines the deformations of the PZT patch. In the perfectly bonded case, this stiffness is evaluated by enforcing continuity between the beam surface strain and a constant normal strain across the PZT patch. In work by Crawley and de Luis (1987), the authors extend the beam’s linear strain vibration across the PZT patch thickness.

Substituting equation (2) into equations (4) and (5), the kinetic and strain energy equations for the ith element become: (6)Ti=12∫0L(ρbAb+ρpAp){(1Nd·i)(1Nd·i)+[x2(Ndi)(Ndi)]θ·2 +2(1Nd·i)xθ·}dx
(7)Ui=12∫0L(EI¯)(N″di)(N″di)dx

Respectively, in which N″=∂2N(x)/∂x2. Following the work of Crawley and de Luis (1987), the virtual work done by the PZT layer and the hub for the perfectly bonded case can be given as: (8)δWi=λiu(t)δθ+cVi(t)[N'(L)-N'(0)]δdi where Vi(t) is the control voltage to the ith PZT, λi u(t) is the portion of the hub input torque delivered to the ith element (0 < λi < 1), and c is a constant defined as: (9)c=12Epd31wp(tp+tb) where d31 is the dielectric constant for the PZT, wp and tp are its width and thickness, tb is the thickness of the beam and Ep denotes the Young’s modulus of the PZT. From equation (8), the generalized forces associated with the beam deformation, Qd,i, and the hub rotation Qθ,i are: (10)Qd,i=c Vi(t)[N'(L)-N'(0)]T,Qd,i=λiu(t)

Next, the Lagrange equations for the ith element is given by: (11a)ddt[∂Ti∂d·i]-∂Ti∂di+∂Ui∂di=Qd,i and (11b)ddt[∂Ti∂θ·]-∂Ti∂θ+∂Ui∂θ=Qθ,i where ddt[∂Ti∂d·i]=(ρbAb+ρpAp) ×([∫0LNTN dx]d··i+[∫0LNxdx·]θ··) and [∂Ti∂d·i]=(ρbAb+ρpAp)([∫0LNTNdx]θ·2d·i),[∂Ui∂di]=EI¯[∫0LN″TN″dx]θ·2di,
ddt[∂Ti∂θ·]=(ρbAb+ρpAp)(2θ·diT[∫0LNTNdx]d·i) +(θ··diT[∫0LNTNdx]+θ··∫0Lx2dx +[∫0LNxdx]d·i)
∂Ti∂θ=0 and ∂Ui∂θ=0

Expressing these equations in a matrix form produces: (12)[MAATdiTMdi+D][d··iθ··]+[0-Mθdiθ·diTMdiTMd·i][d·iθ·] +[K0][diθ]=[Qd,iQθ,i] where M=(ρbAb+ρpAp)[∫0LNTNdx],A=(ρbAb+ρpAp)[∫0LNTxdx]
K=EI¯[∫0LNTN″dx],D=(ρbAb+ρpAp)∫0Lx2dx

The model for the entire flexible beam is formed by assembling a series of the element equations given by equation (11). For those domains of the assembly where the PZT layer of the material is absent, Ap in the corresponding element equations is set to zero, the homogeneous flexural rigidity (EI) is replaced by the product EbIb and Vi = 0. The assembled (global) equation of motion is given by: [MGAGAGTJθ][d··Gθ··]+[0-MGθ·dGθ·dGTMGdGTMGd·G][d·Gθ·] +[KG0][dGθ]=[FGU(t)](13) where Jθ=∑i=12n-1(diTMidi+Di). The top row of equation (13) is a set of (2n) equations defining the evolution of the nodal d.f., dG, accounting for clamped boundary condition at the hub: dy(0) = Ф(0) = 0. The bottom row governs the evolution of the hub angle (θ), given the current beam state, the applied PZT forces and the hub torque τ. The system matrices in relation (13) are of a big size and depend upon the number of elements into which the flexible structure is divided. It is difficult to design the state feedback controller in this form.

The analytical model, as described in the next sub-section with reduced dimensions, is suitable for controller design. The natural frequencies and mode shapes are calculated using FEM technique and are used in the analytical model. The modal damping ratios to be used in the analytical model are determined experimentally.

sec.title: 3.2. Analytical modeling of flexible link
sec.p: The Euler Bernoulli beam theory and assumed modes method can be used to express the deflection at a point located at a distance x from the hub i.e. (14)w(x,t)=∑i=1Nφi(x)qi(t) where qi(t) is the generalized coordinate of the ith mode, N is the number of modes to be considered and φi(x) is the normalized clamp-free eigenfunctions of the ith mode. In the present case the first two modes are considered. The linearized equations of motion of the flexible link can be derived as given by Geniele et al. (1997). (15)[m1m2Tm2m3]{θ··q··}+[C100C2]{θ·q·}+[000-k1]{θ·q·} ={τ(t)0}
In compact form it can be written as (16)[M]{θ··q··}+[C]{θ·q·}+[K]{θ·q·}={τ(t)0} with tip position is as (17)y(L)=∑i=1Nφi(L)qi(t) where (18)m1=Ih+mL33+Mp[L2+(∑i=1Nφi(L)qi(t))2]
In the above equation ‘m’ and ‘Mp’ is the mass of the tip load. ‘Ih’ is the moment of inertia of the hub around the axis of the motor.
In equation (21), ‘b’ is the coefficient of friction between the balls and the outer race of the bearings (22)C2=[2ω1c10…002ω2c2…0:::00…2ωNcN]

In the above equation, ‘ci’ denotes the damping ratio of the ith mode of the clamp-free eigenfunction and ωi is the resonance frequency of the ith clamp-free eigenfunction (23)k1=m[ω120…00ω22…0:::00…ωN2]

The system is a single input (i.e. only torque is applied at the input), two output system with the hub angle as the first output and voltage developed in the PZT sensor as the second output. If the tip displacement is also to be covered, in the equation form it is written as in Geniele et al. (1997) (24)y=[100{s}ϒ0t]{θq} where (25)s=[(∂w1∂x|x=x2-∂w1∂x|x=x1)(∂w2∂x|x=x2-∂w2∂x|x=x1) ……(∂wN∂x|x=x2-∂wN∂x|x=x1)]
(26)t=[(w1|x=x2) (w2|x=x2)…………(wN|x=x2)]

In the above relation, ∂wi∂x|x=x1 is the slope of the flexible link at a distance ‘xi’ from the hub for the ith mode. ϒ is the conversion factor for converting the slope difference into the voltage generated in PZT layer given by Geniele et al. (1997). It depends on the electrical properties of the piezoelectric material as shown in Table 1 below. Table 1.
Electrical properties of PZT
Property Symbol Value
Piezoelectric charge constant (m V−1) d31 171 × 10−12
Electromechanical coupling factor k31 0.12
Piezoelectric voltage constant (VmN−1) g31 216 × 10−3
Dielectric constant k3t 12

Linear quadratic Gaussian control is easy to design in state space form like:- (27)A=[0I-M-1K-M-1C],
(28)BB=[000M-1],

By applying the voltage to the PZT patch, actuation can be produced in the slewing beam. This forms the multi-input multi-output system. The system can be modified to two input system using F1 and F2 with (29)F1=[0(4N-1)x1103Nx1] and (30)F2=[0(4N-1)x10{s}Ψ]

Ψ is the conversion factor for converting the voltage applied to the PZT patch into the slope difference between the edges of the PZT layer such that (31)B=BB*[F1 F2]
(32)C=[100{s}ϒ0t]
(33)D=0

The resultant flexible link system is a two input (one at the hub and other at PZT actuator), three output (first as hub angle, second at the PZT sensor and third as tip displacement) system. If the matrix D is not zero, the systems now can be written as (34)x·(t)=Ax(t)+Bu(t)y(t)=Cx(t)+Du(t)
From any one single input (PZT patch) to a single output (other PZT patch), the system can also be written as (35)G(s)=∑i=1M-φiφi's2+2ςiωis+ωi2

Table 2 below shows the comparison of experimental and theoretical results. The vibration characteristics like natural frequencies are compared with each other. The difference between the theoretically calculated natural frequencies and the experimentally measured is much less and can be ignored to calculate the open loop system in state space form. Damping ratios are not easy to calculate theoretically hence the comparison with theoretical results is very difficult. Experimentally determined damping ratios are used for system modeling. Table 2.
Comparison of theoretical and experimental results
Natural frequencies Damping ratios
mode 1 mode 2 mode 1 mode 2
Theoretical 2.59 Hz 8.50 Hz - -
Experimental 2.45 Hz 8.10 Hz 0.006 0.004

sec.title: 4. Positive position feedback control at PZT actuator
sec.p: A number of control design techniques are available that guarantee unconditional closed loop stability and add sufficient damping to the system. Velocity feedback and resonant controllers are two examples of such systems. The PPF controller does not guarantee unconditional stability of the closed loop system; however, it does guarantee stability in the presence of uncontrolled in-bandwidth modes, and it has the additional property that it rolls off quickly at high frequencies.

sec.title: 4.1. Preliminaries of positive position feedback (PPF) control
sec.p: For a system of the form as in equation (35), a PPF controller is given as (36)Kn(s)=∑i=1n-αiαis2+2δiψis+ψi2

The existence of a negative term in equation (36), the overall system resembles a PPF loop. The important property of the PPF control is that its structure resembles the flexible system shown in (35). A second order controller is required for a single vibration mode of the flexible structure. Simple PPF control has a second order compensator which acts as a positive feedback controller as shown below in Figure 2. Based on the number of modes to be controlled, the number of such compensators can be increased with connection parallel to each other. The compensator frequency ψi is normally is taken as the same as of the flexible structure i.e. ωn. The damping ratio δi of the compensator is different from the damping factor ςi of the flexible structure mode (i.e. open loop system). Figure 2.
Block diagram of simple positive position feedback (PPF) control.

sec.title: 4.2. Standard stability criterion
sec.p:
For explaining the stability of the closed loop (CL) system with PPF control, following theorems are necessary.Theorem 1
Consider the following multivariable system (37)q··(t)+Dq·(t)+Kq(t)=0
The system (37) is exponentially stable if, and only if,
K = K′ > 0 by assuming D = D′ > 0.Theorem 2
By making the following definitions N=[η1η2ηn], Ω=[ω1ω2ωn], (38a,b)
Δ=[δ1δ2δn], Ψ=[ψ1ψ1ψ1], (38c,d)
(38e)Φ=[φ1φ2…φn] and (38f)Λ=[α1α2…αn].
It is also assumed that (39)Δ>0
The theorem says that the negative feedback connection of (36) and (35) with (39) is exponentially stable if, and only if, (40a)Ψ2-Λ'DΛ>0 and (40b)Ω2-Φ'Λ(Ψ2-Λ'DΛ)-1Λ'Φ>0

sec.title: 4.3. Stability considerations using H2 or H∞ norm calculations
sec.p: The H2 norm of the flexible structure represented by transfer function G(s) can be used as a performance measure. In mathematical form it can be represented as in Maciejowski (1989) (41a) ‖G‖22=12π∫-∞∞tr{G(jω)*G(jω)}dω and can be calculated using standard software. Similarly the H∞ norm is defined as the maximum overshoot of the output in the frequency domain. The purpose of the controller is to reduce the effect of disturbances acting on the system and can be obtained by moving the poles of the closed loop system towards the farthest point in the negative direction in the left hand side of the imaginary plane. By doing so, necessary damping can be provided to the structure. The simplest way to do this is to reduce the closed loop system’s H2 norm or H∞ norm as small as possible. The problem of stability will be automatically solved by this method. The H2 norm of an unstable closed loop system does not make any sense; hence minimum value of this norm can only be obtained when the closed loop system is stable. The CL performance of the control system is also dependent on open loop zeros of the system.

These zeros are accurately identified by using the feed through term. Currently available techniques of designing optimal PPF controller don’t allow for a feed through term in the model of the flexible structure.

Only Moheimani et al. (2006) have attempted this problem successfully. Using the proposed method of PPF controller design, system can be represented in the form shown in equation (35). It is difficult to find the H2 norm in this form using standard software.

However this problem can be corrected (Maciejowski, 1989). Similarly H∞ norm of the flexible structure represented by transfer function G(s) can be used as a performance measure. In mathematical form it can be represented as (41b) ‖G‖∞=supωσ¯{G(jω)}

A control engineering interpretation of the infinity norm of a scalar transfer function G is the distance in the complex plane from the origin to the farthest point on the Nyquist plot of G, and it also appears as the peak value on the Bode magnitude plot of |G(jω)|. Normally H∞ norm of G(s) can be regarded as the largest possible amplification factor of the system’s steady state response to sinusoidal excitation. For example, the steady-state response of the system with respect to sinusoidal input u(t)=Usin(ω0t+φ) is y(t)=U|G(jω0)|sin(ω0t+φ+∠G(jω0)) and thus the maximum possible amplification factor is sup|G(jω0)|ω0, is precisely the H∞ norm of the transfer function.

sec.title: 5. Linear quadratic gaussian control
sec.p: For a linear system given by equation (34) if all the states of the system are controllable, the system is said to be completely controllable. The controllability of the system depends on system matrices A and B. The controllability matrix is given by Maciejowski (1989) (42a)U0=[BABA2B………An-1B] where ‘n’ is the order of the system matrix A. If the rank of the controllability matrix is equal to the order of system matrix A, then it is called controllable, otherwise it is said to be uncontrollable. It may be mentioned here that even if the system is not controllable, it may work satisfactorily. If the system represented by the matrices A and B is not completely controllable, it may be decomposed into controllable and uncontrollable parts. When the uncontrollable part is stable, only then is the optimal solution is possible, (Maciejowski, 1989). So stability, not the controllability, is the necessary condition for an optimal solution. The system matrices are checked for this test for controllability before designing the controller. Observability means that the states of a system can be determined from a finite number of its most recent inputs and outputs. The observability matrix M0 is defined by the following relation (42b)M0=[CCA:CAn-1]

If the rank of the observability matrix is equal to the order of the system matrix A, the system is completely observable otherwise it is not (Maciejowski, 1989). If the system is not completely observable, all the modes of the system are not observable. So the system matrices are checked for this test for observability before designing the observer.

Due to various uncertainties the system dynamics is not constant. In such situations, LQR is found to be an excellent robust control system design methodology (Maciejowski, 1989). Let the system to be controlled be written in state space form as (43)X·(t)=AX(t)+Bu(t)+Γwy(t)=CX(t)+v where w and v are the ‘white noises’, namely zero-mean Gaussian stochastic processes which are uncorrelated in time, having covariances (44a)E{wwT}=W≥0, E{vvT}=V>0
It is assumed that w and v are uncorrelated with each other namely (44b)E{wvT}=0

In optimal control problem it is to find the input u (t), to the plant such that a scalar quadratic cost function (45)J1=limT→∞E{∫0T(zTQz+uTRu)dt} where (46)z=MX is some linear combination of states. Q and R are symmetric positive semi-definite and symmetric positive definite matrices, respectively. The method to find the values of these matrices is given at the end of the present section. A controller having gain matrix K is related with solution matrix Pc by the following equation (47)K=R-1BTPc
Where Pc satisfy the algebraic Riccati equation (48)ATPc+PcA-PcBR-1BTPc+MTQM=0
Using the gain matrix K, control inputs are calculated by the following equation (49)u(t)=-KX(t)
This gain matrix minimizes the cost function shown in relation (46) on the assumption that (50)X·(t)=AX(t)+Bu(t)
The gain matrix K is evaluated using the MATLAB, by giving the value of matrices A, B, C, Q and R as input. The values of weighing matrices R and Q are selected as discussed below.
The state weighing matrix Q is chosen as Q=[1x1200001x2200001x3200001x42]
Where X = [x1 x2 x3 x4]T is the amplitude of state vector. The weighing matrix R is chosen as R=[1u12001u22] where u = [u1 u2]T is the amplitude of input vector.

sec.title: 5.1. Measurement of noise characteristics
sec.p: It is important to estimate the noise characteristics of the measurement system so that accurate behavior of the overall system can be predicted. The noise characteristics of the measurement system consist of measurement noise and process noise. Since the measurement covariance matrix V and process covariance matrix W are required in Kalman filter calculations, these must be known before designing the Kalman filter. These matrices depend upon measurement noise and process noise. Therefore, a mathematical model of the noise sequences is necessary. The measurement noise and process noise are assumed to be zero mean. The following method is adopted to characterize the noise sequences.

A periodic input allows the estimate of noise level in the system. After the transient effects have disappeared, the differences in output response over the different periods must be attributed to the noise sources. Let the output be defined by the relation (51a)y~(t)=y∧(t)+v⌢(t) where y∧(t) is the noise-free part that originates from the input and v⌢(t) is the measurement noise vector. Since the measurement error has been considered as zero mean, the noise free part of the signal is obtained by repeating the experiment several (say S) times for an input sequence and taking the average of that output sequence. Then (51b)y∧i(j)=1S ∑j=1S y~i(j) for i=1to L
This gives the measurement noise estimates as (51c)v⌢(i)=y~(i)-y∧(i) for i=1to L
The noise variance vector λv = [λv1 λv2]T is estimated as λvk=1L∑i=1Lv⌢k2
The measurement covariance matrix V is constructed from the noise variance matrix using the following relation V=[λv100λ2]
V is a symmetric semi-definite positive matrix. Let w⌢(k) be the process noise vector.
The equations giving the system state from the averaged measured outputs are given as, (Maciejowski, 1989) [CCA]x∧(k)=ℜx∧(k)=[y∧(k)y∧(k+1)]=z∧ (say)
Their least square estimate is given by (52a)x∧(k)=(ℜTℜ)-1ℜTz∧
The process noise vector at any time instant I can be found from the following relation (52b)w⌢(i)=x~(i)-x∧(i) for i=1to L

In the above relation x~(i) for i = 1 to L, is the averaged state vector sequence obtained by averaging the response from S number of experiments. The noise variance vector λw = [λw1 λw2 λw3 λw4] is estimated as λwk=1L∑i=1L{w⌢k2(i)}
The process noise covariance matrices W is obtained as below W=[λw10000λw20000λw30000λw4]
W is a symmetric semi-definite positive matrix. After calculating these matrices it is easy to design the Kalman filter.

sec.title: 5.2. Kalman filter design
sec.p: Normally input-output data is available from experimental set-up. Due to the presence of ‘measurement noise’ and ‘process noise’ the system state and output equations of the stochastic system has the following form, (Maciejowski, 1989) X·(t)=AX(t)+Bu(t)+Γwy(t)=CX(t)+v

To estimate the states of the system some form of estimator is required. In the present work the Kalman filter is used as an estimator. The Kalman filter gain matrix L is given by Maciejowski (1989) (53)L=PfCTV-1 where Pf satisfies another algebraic equation (54)PfAT+APf-PfCTV-1CPf+ΓWΓT=0 and Pf=PfT≥0
The matrices K and L exist, and the closed loop system is internally stable, provided the system with state space realizations (A, B, Q1/2 M) and (A,ΓW1/2,C) are stablizable and detectable.

By substituting equations (50) in (44) there follows (55)X·=(A-BK)X as the equation of the closed loop system which would result if full state optimal feedback were implemented. The eigenvalues of A-BK lie on the left half plane eigenvalue of the following Hamiltonian matrix (56)H=[A-BR-1BT-MTQM-AT] which shows the optimal hypothetical state-feedback scheme to be asymptotically stable.
The state equation of the Kalman filter can be written as (57)ddtX∧=(A-LC)X+Bu+Ly
The eigen values of A-LC can be shown to be the left half-plane eigen values of the Hamiltonian matrix for the filter problem.

sec.title: 6. Instabilities due to hardware filters in the control loop
sec.p: The presence of a DC component in the signal obtained from Data Acquisition card is unavoidable.

A high pass filter with 1.0 Hz cut off frequency is usually used. Also, to avoid the problem of control spillover a low pass filter is used with cut-off frequency near the highest mode to be controlled. The frequency response function (magnitude only) is presented in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Frequency response function of multi-input multi-output single link flexible manipulator.

When a high pass filter (which has a cut off frequency of 1.2 Hz), as shown in Figure 4, is used to distort the phase of the FRF of the open loop (OL) system near the first natural frequency. In this case the PPF controller design loses its effectiveness if the high pass (HP) filter is placed in series with the OL system. Figure 4.
High pass filter used to remove DC signal.

The first natural frequency is 2.59 Hz and the second natural frequency is 8.50 Hz at zero tip load. Figure 5 shows this phenomenon as below. Without an HP filter the magnitude reduction in 24 dB. However, the presence of HP filter reduces the system performance to almost zero. Figure 5.
Effect of LP and HP filters on the performance of closed loop system with positive position feedback (PPF) control.

sec.title: 7. Effective positive position feedback (PPF) control design in presence of hardware filters using pattern search techniques
7.1. Terminology and working of pattern search algorithm
sec.p: A pattern search algorithm computes a sequence of points that get closer and closer to the optimal point. At each step, the algorithm searches for a set of points, called a mesh, around the current point - the point computed at the previous step of the algorithm. The algorithm forms the mesh by adding the current point to a scalar multiple of a fixed set of vectors called a pattern. If the algorithm finds a point in the mesh that improves the objective function at the current point, the new point becomes the current point at the next step of the algorithm.

The terminology and how the pattern search technique works is discussed in brief below.
Patterns
A pattern is a collection of vectors that the algorithm uses to determine which points to search at each iteration. Meshes
At each step, the pattern search algorithm searches a set of points, called a mesh, for a point that improves the objective function. The algorithm forms the mesh by a) Multiplying the pattern vectors by a scalar, called the mesh size b) Adding the resulting vectors to the current point - the point with the best objective function value found at the previous step. Polling
At each step, the algorithm polls the points in the current mesh by computing their objective function values. When the option complete poll has the default setting off, the algorithm stops polling the mesh points as soon as it finds a point whose objective function value is less than that of the current point. If this occurs, the poll is called successful and the point it finds becomes the current point at the next iteration. Note that the algorithm only computes the mesh points and their objective function values up to the point at which it stops the poll. If the algorithm fails to find a point that improves the objective function, the poll is called unsuccessful and the current point stays the same at the next iteration. If the complete poll is set to on, the algorithm computes the objective function values at all mesh points. The algorithm then compares the mesh point with the smallest objective function value to the current point. If that mesh point has a smaller value than the current point, the poll is successful.

Generally speaking, pattern search methods generate a sequence of iterates {x(k)} without using any information of the derivatives, including gradient and second-order derivative, of the objective function. They only depend on function values. In fact, ordinal information about function values is enough. At each iteration, the objective function is evaluated at a finite number of trial points (defined below) and the purpose is to look for one point which can yield a lower function value than the current iterate. If such a point is found, it is set to be the new iterate, and the iteration is called successful; Otherwise, it is declared unsuccessful and update the trial points. In Torczon’s generalized pattern search method, two components are needed, one is a pattern P(k), and the other one is a real scale factor Δ(k) > 0.

The pattern P(k) consists of a basis matrix A and a generating matrix C(k). Among them, any non-singular matrix in ℝnxn could be chosen as A and C(k)∈ℤn x p(p>2n) could be partitioned into three parts: (58)C(k)=[M(k)-M(k)D(k)] where M(k)∈M⊂ℤnx n, M is a finite set of non-singular matrices, D(k)∈ℤn x(p-2n) contains at least one column, the column of zeros.
Then P(k) could be written as (59)P(k)=AC(k)=[AM(k)-AM(k)AD(k)].

It is noted that because both the basis matrix A and the generating matrix C(k) have rank n, the columns of P(k) can span ℝn. The real scale factor Δ(k) works as a step length parameter. Let C(k)=[c1(k),c2(k),…,cp(k)], then a trial step si(k) is defined as any vector of the form (60)si(k)=Δ(k)Aci(k)
In fact, Aci(k) determines the direction of the step and at iteration k, all the trial points possess the form of (61)xi(k)=x(k)+si(k) where x(k) is the current iterate.
Then a generalized pattern search method could be outlined as follows:
Let initial iterate x(0)∈ℝn, A∈ℝnx n, C(0)∈ℤnx p, Δ(0)>0, k = 0.

While (Stopping conditions do not hold) do
Step 1
Find a step s(k) using Exploratory Moves (Δ(k), AC(k)). Step 2
If f(x(k) + s(k)) < f(x(k)), where ‘f’ is the objective function, then x(k + 1) = x(k) + s(k). Otherwise, x(k + 1) = x(k). Step 3
Update C(k) and Δ (k) to C(k + 1) and Δ(k + 1), k = k + 1.

sec.title: 7.2. Flowchart for effective positive position feedback (PPF) controller and compensator
sec.p: However, due to the phase lead/lag produced by the filters and the system delay (which is neglected in the present case due to the use of real time controller boards), the CL system with simple PPF controller looses efficiency and sometimes gets unstable. To get optimal results, the low pass (LP) and HP should be considered while designing the efficient PPF controller.

Figure 6 shows the block diagram of the proposed Efficient PPF control. To avoid the decreased efficiency of the closed loop system (with simple PPF controller) with phase change caused by filters, lead/lag compensator should be added in series with the PPF controller. Figure 6.
Block diagram for effective positive position feedback (PPF) control using compensators.

Figure 7 shows the block diagram of the lead/lag compensator circuit (Geniele et al., 1997). The capacitance values are fixed as in this figure. However, the resistance values are designed simultaneously with the PPF controller. The transfer function of the compensator is given as (62)TF=(s+1R1C1)(s+1R2C2)s2+(1R1C1+1R2C2+1R2C1)s+1R1R2C1C2
Figure 7.
Block diagram of lead/lag compensator circuit.

Figure 8(a) as shown below presents the flowchart to design the effective PPF controller. Figure 8(a).
Flowchart for the design of effective positive position feedback (PPF) controller and compensator; (b) Flowchart for the detailed design of effective positive position feedback (PPF) controller and compensator.
According to this flow chart, first of all the parameters ωi,δiandφifor i=1:n are fixed and the value of capacitances C1 and C2 is also fixed as clear from Figure 7 above.

The values δi=ηiandψi=ωifor i=1:n are fixed and αifor i=1:n are chosen arbitrarily. The PPF controller is designed with these parameters and afterwards the H2 or H∞ norm of the closed loop system is calculated. With the help of the pattern search tool, the values of αifor i=1:n are optimized in such a way that minimum H2 or H∞ norm is produced. After optimization α1andα2 are found to be 486 and 3 respectively. The LP, HP filter and compensation circuit are represented in transfer function form and are connected with the OL system in series to form a modified OL system. The PPF controller is connected in feedback with this modified OL system to form a CL system. The next step is to calculate the H2 norm of the CL system. Then the mesh size of the pattern search algorithm is reduced to further decrease the H2 norm of the CL system. If further improvement is there the control is shifted back to the step where new parameters of the PPF controller are fed. In this manner the loop continues to search for a PPF controller along with compensation circuit to find the lowest H2 norm of the CL system. Figure 8(a) above represents the flowchart to design the PPF controller. With the designed PPF controller, CL magnitude is much smaller than the OL magnitude.

Figure 8(b) above represents a flowchart for the detailed design of the controller. It is a type-I PPF controller. Amplitude reduction of 24 dB is obtained in the ideal case. With the application of filters the amplitude reduction decreases to 14 dB. Figure 9 below shows the CL response of the system with HP and LP filter. Figure 9.
Closed loop frequency domain performance of the system with type-I effective positive position feedback (PPF) controller along with compensator.

The beauty of this method is that it is not necessary to set any constraint during this minimization (of H2 norm). After minimization only the lowest H2 or H∞ norm of the closed loop is obtained. If any HP or LP filter is to be used, the modified OL system is obtained by connecting these filters in series with original open loop system.

Now the procedure to design the type-II PPF is explained. First of all the system is constructed in the form shown by relation (35) so that the parameters ωi,δiandφifor i=1:n are available for controller design. Afterwards, a LP filter and HP filter is constructed based on the required specifications. Initial parameters for the PPF controller like R1,R2αiandδifor i=1:n are chosen arbitrarily. In the second step, the parameters of the PPF controller are chosen such that δi≠ηiandψi≠ωifor i=1:n. i.e. it is not necessary to keep δi=ηi. It further decreases the H∞ norm of the CL system. This is called type-II PPF controller. The compensator is attached in series with the original controller to design a modified controller. The need for the compensator arises due to the presence of hardware filters. With this modified controller the performance improves a lot even in the presence of filters. After optimization, α1andα2 are found to be 1468.28 and 1 respectively. δ1andδ2 are found to be 1 and 1 respectively in this case. An analog compensator circuit is used here. In the type-II PPF controller, using compensator, the magnitude of the CL system further decreases to such a value that overall reduction in amplitude is 17.4 dB. It is shown in Figure 10 with the improved CL response of the system. Figure 10.
Closed loop frequency domain performance of the system with type-II effective positive position feedback (PPF) controller along with compensator.
The resistances R1 and R2 of the analog compensator circuit are 360 k Ohm and 100 Ohm respectively. Capacitances C1 and C2 are fixed to 0.2 and 0.1 µF.

Figure 11 below shows the time domain response of the single link flexible manipulator. As there is a change in the hub angle from one position to the second position, the signal is obtained from PZT sensor with and without PPF controller. With PPF control excessive vibrations are reduced. Figure 11.
Closed loop time domain performance of the system with type-II effective positive position feedback (PPF) controller along with compensator.

sec.title: 8. Design of effective linear quadratic gaussian control using modified Kalman filter
sec.p:
In the above sections the methods to design the LQR and Kalman filter are discussed in detail. Figure 12 shows the complete system of controllers, filters and compensators to control the single link manipulator. Figure 12.
Schematic for the design of effective linear quadratic Gaussian (LQG) control using compensators.
First of all the secondary feedback for the hub control is discussed. Kalman filter-1 (which is used here) is redesigned by taking the OL system in series with LP and HP filters.

The modified Kalman filter is designed based on this modified OL system. The gain vector K1 is calculated in a usual way by solving the Riccatti equation. The design of primary feedback for the hub is slightly complicated. Following steps are used for this:
In the first step, HP and LP filter are connected as shown above in Figure 12.
The Kalman filter-2 is designed in a usual way. Simulink response toolbox is used to calculate the gain matrix K2. For the time periods t1, t11, t2 and t3 the step response magnitude is arbitrarily decided based on the requirement. Using this tool box (which works on the time response minimization by pattern search toolbox) gain matrix is modified in each iteration. By optimization process K2 is calculated and fixed. K2 = [0.1241 0.0335 0.0114 0.2470 0.2752 −0.0005] gives the satisfactory results.

sec.title: 9. Simulations and experimental data
sec.p:
Figure 13 shows the response of the system (in simulations) by using PPF control while Figure 14 shows the effect of the second feedback from the PZT sensor to the hub along with PPF control as shown below. Figure 13.
Design and closed loop response with of linear quadratic Gaussian (LQG) control applied at hub.
Figure 14.
Effect of PZT sensor feed on the closed loop response with of linear quadratic Gaussian (LQG) control applied at hub and positive position feedback (PPF) controller applied at the PZT patch.

Under the application of both, not only the overshoot decreases but also the signal becomes smooth. Similar response is obtained for tip displacement. The overshoot decreases by 16 Volt by using the second feed (i.e. feed from the PZT sensor). By observing the tip response it is obvious that 7 mm less overshoot is obtained.

Figure 15 shows that if the LP and HP filters are added in the circuit for the secondary feedback through Kalman filter-1, the system becomes unstable. Figure 15.
Instability caused by presence of LP and HP filter for the feed from PVDF (polyvinylidene difluoride) sensor for the control at the hub.

Using modified Kalman filter-1 the response of the system improves to Figure 16 as under:- Figure 16.
Effect of using modified Kalman filter-1on the feed applied from PZT sensor for the control at the hub.

The Kalman filter gain L1 = [2.6054 −11.2510 0.0696 0.0114 15.8962 2.4640] are the modified one. The feedback gain K1 = [−0.0009 −0.0004 −0.8176 0.4315 −0.3185 0.1589] gives satisfactory results. Instead of single overshoot two overshoots in the negative direction are there. The decrease in overshoot is 14.5 volt by using signal from PZT sensor which is used as secondary feedback.

Next is the situation when analog LP and HP filters are connected to the hub control circuit through Kalman filter-2 (see Figure 12). Due to change in system dynamics with the application of filters, the originally designed Kalman filter-2 loses stability. This factor is shown in Figure 17 as under. Figure 17.
Effect of hardware filters on the stability of the system.

Now the Kalman filter-2 is further redesigned by considering the filters in series with the original dynamics of the system. The system regains its stability. The Kalman filter-2 has modified gains of L2 = [17.0117 −0.6558 0.0050 16.7493 −6.5391 0.0772 0.8107 7.2451]. The response of the PZT sensor is shown in Figure 18. Figure 18.
Effect of using modified Kalman filter-2 on the feed applied from PVDF sensor for the control at the hub (positive position feedback (PPF) controller).
The feedback gain K2 = [0.6360 −0.7024 −2.0621 0.7070 0.0515 −0.0482 0.0044 −0.0111] gives satisfactory results. With this second feedback the percent overshoot decreases.

sec.title: 10. Conclusions
sec.p: The presence of hardware filters with the cut-off frequency near the resonant frequency causes a closed loop stability problem in the system. Modified Kalman filters as well as certain hardware compensators can remove the instability problem in the system. Pattern search technique has been used as an efficient design technique to design controllers which otherwise have no systematic way to design them. The PPF controller reduces the overshoot problem, but slight offset from the zero value during initial periods of time remains a major problem. This problem can be solved by using resonant controllers to a considerable extent. Experimental investigations are being carried out and the results will be published in the future.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
